lines.text: MARIANA veiled, ISABELLA, and FRIAR PETER, at their  stand. Enter DUKE VINCENTIO, VARRIUS, Lords,  ANGELO, ESCALUS, LUCIO, Provost, Officers, and Citizens, at several doors

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: My very worthy cousin, fairly met! Our old and faithful friend, we are glad to see you.

lines.speaker: escalus
lines.text: Happy return be to your royal grace!

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: Many and hearty thankings to you both. We have made inquiry of you; and we hear Such goodness of your justice, that our soul Cannot but yield you forth to public thanks, Forerunning more requital.

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: You make my bonds still greater.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: O, your desert speaks loud; and I should wrong it, To lock it in the wards of covert bosom, When it deserves, with characters of brass, A forted residence 'gainst the tooth of time And razure of oblivion. Give me your hand, And let the subject see, to make them know That outward courtesies would fain proclaim Favours that keep within. Come, Escalus, You must walk by us on our other hand; And good supporters are you.
FRIAR PETER and ISABELLA come forward

lines.speaker: friar peter
lines.text: Now is your time: speak loud and kneel before him.

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: Justice, O royal duke! Vail your regard Upon a wrong'd, I would fain have said, a maid! O worthy prince, dishonour not your eye By throwing it on any other object Till you have heard me in my true complaint And given me justice, justice, justice, justice!

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: Relate your wrongs; in what? by whom? be brief. Here is Lord Angelo shall give you justice: Reveal yourself to him.

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: O worthy duke, You bid me seek redemption of the devil: Hear me yourself; for that which I must speak Must either punish me, not being believed, Or wring redress from you. Hear me, O hear me, here!

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: My lord, her wits, I fear me, are not firm: She hath been a suitor to me for her brother Cut off by course of justice,--

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: By course of justice!

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: And she will speak most bitterly and strange.

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: Most strange, but yet most truly, will I speak: That Angelo's forsworn; is it not strange? That Angelo's a murderer; is 't not strange? That Angelo is an adulterous thief, An hypocrite, a virgin-violator; Is it not strange and strange?

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: Nay, it is ten times strange.

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: It is not truer he is Angelo Than this is all as true as it is strange: Nay, it is ten times true; for truth is truth To the end of reckoning.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: Away with her! Poor soul, She speaks this in the infirmity of sense.

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: O prince, I conjure thee, as thou believest There is another comfort than this world, That thou neglect me not, with that opinion That I am touch'd with madness! Make not impossible That which but seems unlike: 'tis not impossible But one, the wicked'st caitiff on the ground, May seem as shy, as grave, as just, as absolute As Angelo; even so may Angelo, In all his dressings, characts, titles, forms, Be an arch-villain; believe it, royal prince: If he be less, he's nothing; but he's more, Had I more name for badness.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: By mine honesty, If she be mad,--as I believe no other,-- Her madness hath the oddest frame of sense, Such a dependency of thing on thing, As e'er I heard in madness.

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: O gracious duke, Harp not on that, nor do not banish reason For inequality; but let your reason serve To make the truth appear where it seems hid, And hide the false seems true.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: Many that are not mad Have, sure, more lack of reason. What would you say?

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: I am the sister of one Claudio, Condemn'd upon the act of fornication To lose his head; condemn'd by Angelo: I, in probation of a sisterhood, Was sent to by my brother; one Lucio As then the messenger,--

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: That's I, an't like your grace: I came to her from Claudio, and desired her To try her gracious fortune with Lord Angelo For her poor brother's pardon.

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: That's he indeed.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: You were not bid to speak.

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: No, my good lord; Nor wish'd to hold my peace.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: I wish you now, then; Pray you, take note of it: and when you have A business for yourself, pray heaven you then Be perfect.

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: I warrant your honour.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: The warrants for yourself; take heed to't.

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: This gentleman told somewhat of my tale,--

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: Right.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: It may be right; but you are i' the wrong To speak before your time. Proceed.

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: I went To this pernicious caitiff deputy,--

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: That's somewhat madly spoken.

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: Pardon it; The phrase is to the matter.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: Mended again. The matter; proceed.

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: In brief, to set the needless process by, How I persuaded, how I pray'd, and kneel'd, How he refell'd me, and how I replied,-- For this was of much length,--the vile conclusion I now begin with grief and shame to utter: He would not, but by gift of my chaste body To his concupiscible intemperate lust, Release my brother; and, after much debatement, My sisterly remorse confutes mine honour, And I did yield to him: but the next morn betimes, His purpose surfeiting, he sends a warrant For my poor brother's head.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: This is most likely!

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: O, that it were as like as it is true!

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: By heaven, fond wretch, thou knowist not what thou speak'st, Or else thou art suborn'd against his honour In hateful practise. First, his integrity Stands without blemish. Next, it imports no reason That with such vehemency he should pursue Faults proper to himself: if he had so offended, He would have weigh'd thy brother by himself And not have cut him off. Some one hath set you on: Confess the truth, and say by whose advice Thou camest here to complain.

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: And is this all? Then, O you blessed ministers above, Keep me in patience, and with ripen'd time Unfold the evil which is here wrapt up In countenance! Heaven shield your grace from woe, As I, thus wrong'd, hence unbelieved go!

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: I know you'ld fain be gone. An officer! To prison with her! Shall we thus permit A blasting and a scandalous breath to fall On him so near us? This needs must be a practise. Who knew of Your intent and coming hither?

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: One that I would were here, Friar Lodowick.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: A ghostly father, belike. Who knows that Lodowick?

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: My lord, I know him; 'tis a meddling friar; I do not like the man: had he been lay, my lord For certain words he spake against your grace In your retirement, I had swinged him soundly.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: Words against me? this is a good friar, belike! And to set on this wretched woman here Against our substitute! Let this friar be found.

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: But yesternight, my lord, she and that friar, I saw them at the prison: a saucy friar, A very scurvy fellow.

lines.speaker: friar peter
lines.text: Blessed be your royal grace! I have stood by, my lord, and I have heard Your royal ear abused. First, hath this woman Most wrongfully accused your substitute, Who is as free from touch or soil with her As she from one ungot.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: We did believe no less. Know you that Friar Lodowick that she speaks of?

lines.speaker: friar peter
lines.text: I know him for a man divine and holy; Not scurvy, nor a temporary meddler, As he's reported by this gentleman; And, on my trust, a man that never yet Did, as he vouches, misreport your grace.

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: My lord, most villanously; believe it.

lines.speaker: friar peter
lines.text: Well, he in time may come to clear himself; But at this instant he is sick my lord, Of a strange fever. Upon his mere request, Being come to knowledge that there was complaint Intended 'gainst Lord Angelo, came I hither, To speak, as from his mouth, what he doth know Is true and false; and what he with his oath And all probation will make up full clear, Whensoever he's convented. First, for this woman. To justify this worthy nobleman, So vulgarly and personally accused, Her shall you hear disproved to her eyes, Till she herself confess it.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: Good friar, let's hear it. ISABELLA is carried off guarded; and MARIANA comes forward Do you not smile at this, Lord Angelo? O heaven, the vanity of wretched fools! Give us some seats. Come, cousin Angelo; In this I'll be impartial; be you judge Of your own cause. Is this the witness, friar? First, let her show her face, and after speak.

lines.speaker: mariana
lines.text: Pardon, my lord; I will not show my face Until my husband bid me.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: What, are you married?

lines.speaker: mariana
lines.text: No, my lord.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: Are you a maid?

lines.speaker: mariana
lines.text: No, my lord.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: A widow, then?

lines.speaker: mariana
lines.text: Neither, my lord.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: Why, you are nothing then: neither maid, widow, nor wife?

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: My lord, she may be a punk; for many of them are neither maid, widow, nor wife.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: Silence that fellow: I would he had some cause To prattle for himself.

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: Well, my lord.

lines.speaker: mariana
lines.text: My lord; I do confess I ne'er was married; And I confess besides I am no maid: I have known my husband; yet my husband Knows not that ever he knew me.

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: He was drunk then, my lord: it can be no better.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: For the benefit of silence, would thou wert so too!

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: Well, my lord.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: This is no witness for Lord Angelo.

lines.speaker: mariana
lines.text: Now I come to't my lord She that accuses him of fornication, In self-same manner doth accuse my husband, And charges him my lord, with such a time When I'll depose I had him in mine arms With all the effect of love.

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: Charges she more than me?

lines.speaker: mariana
lines.text: Not that I know.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: No? you say your husband.

lines.speaker: mariana
lines.text: Why, just, my lord, and that is Angelo, Who thinks he knows that he ne'er knew my body, But knows he thinks that he knows Isabel's.

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: This is a strange abuse. Let's see thy face.

lines.speaker: mariana
lines.text: My husband bids me; now I will unmask. This is that face, thou cruel Angelo, Which once thou sworest was worth the looking on; This is the hand which, with a vow'd contract, Was fast belock'd in thine; this is the body That took away the match from Isabel, And did supply thee at thy garden-house In her imagined person.
Unveiling

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: Know you this woman?

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: Carnally, she says.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: Sirrah, no more!

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: Enough, my lord.

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: My lord, I must confess I know this woman: And five years since there was some speech of marriage Betwixt myself and her; which was broke off, Partly for that her promised proportions Came short of composition, but in chief For that her reputation was disvalued In levity: since which time of five years I never spake with her, saw her, nor heard from her, Upon my faith and honour.

lines.speaker: mariana
lines.text: Noble prince, As there comes light from heaven and words from breath, As there is sense in truth and truth in virtue, I am affianced this man's wife as strongly As words could make up vows: and, my good lord, But Tuesday night last gone in's garden-house He knew me as a wife. As this is true, Let me in safety raise me from my knees Or else for ever be confixed here, A marble monument!

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: I did but smile till now: Now, good my lord, give me the scope of justice My patience here is touch'd. I do perceive These poor informal women are no more But instruments of some more mightier member That sets them on: let me have way, my lord, To find this practise out.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: Ay, with my heart And punish them to your height of pleasure. Thou foolish friar, and thou pernicious woman, Compact with her that's gone, think'st thou thy oaths, Though they would swear down each particular saint, Were testimonies against his worth and credit That's seal'd in approbation? You, Lord Escalus, Sit with my cousin; lend him your kind pains To find out this abuse, whence 'tis derived. There is another friar that set them on; Let him be sent for.

lines.speaker: friar peter
lines.text: Would he were here, my lord! for he indeed Hath set the women on to this complaint: Your provost knows the place where he abides And he may fetch him.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: Go do it instantly. And you, my noble and well-warranted cousin, Whom it concerns to hear this matter forth, Do with your injuries as seems you best, In any chastisement: I for a while will leave you; But stir not you till you have well determined Upon these slanderers.
Exit Provost

lines.speaker: escalus
lines.text: My lord, we'll do it throughly. Signior Lucio, did not you say you knew that Friar Lodowick to be a dishonest person?
Exit DUKE

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: 'Cucullus non facit monachum:' honest in nothing but in his clothes; and one that hath spoke most villanous speeches of the duke.

lines.speaker: escalus
lines.text: We shall entreat you to abide here till he come and enforce them against him: we shall find this friar a notable fellow.

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: As any in Vienna, on my word.

lines.speaker: escalus
lines.text: Call that same Isabel here once again; I would speak with her. Pray you, my lord, give me leave to question; you shall see how I'll handle her.
Exit an Attendant

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: Not better than he, by her own report.

lines.speaker: escalus
lines.text: Say you?

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: Marry, sir, I think, if you handled her privately, she would sooner confess: perchance, publicly, she'll be ashamed.

lines.speaker: escalus
lines.text: I will go darkly to work with her.

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: That's the way; for women are light at midnight. Re-enter Officers with ISABELLA; and Provost with the DUKE VINCENTIO in his friar's habit

lines.speaker: escalus
lines.text: Come on, mistress: here's a gentlewoman denies all that you have said.

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: My lord, here comes the rascal I spoke of; here with the provost.

lines.speaker: escalus
lines.text: In very good time: speak not you to him till we call upon you.

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: Mum.

lines.speaker: escalus
lines.text: Come, sir: did you set these women on to slander Lord Angelo? they have confessed you did.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: 'Tis false.

lines.speaker: escalus
lines.text: How! know you where you are?

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: Respect to your great place! and let the devil Be sometime honour'd for his burning throne! Where is the duke? 'tis he should hear me speak.

lines.speaker: escalus
lines.text: The duke's in us; and we will hear you speak: Look you speak justly.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: Boldly, at least. But, O, poor souls, Come you to seek the lamb here of the fox? Good night to your redress! Is the duke gone? Then is your cause gone too. The duke's unjust, Thus to retort your manifest appeal, And put your trial in the villain's mouth Which here you come to accuse.

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: This is the rascal; this is he I spoke of.

lines.speaker: escalus
lines.text: Why, thou unreverend and unhallow'd friar, Is't not enough thou hast suborn'd these women To accuse this worthy man, but, in foul mouth And in the witness of his proper ear, To call him villain? and then to glance from him To the duke himself, to tax him with injustice? Take him hence; to the rack with him! We'll touse you Joint by joint, but we will know his purpose. What 'unjust'!

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: Be not so hot; the duke Dare no more stretch this finger of mine than he Dare rack his own: his subject am I not, Nor here provincial. My business in this state Made me a looker on here in Vienna, Where I have seen corruption boil and bubble Till it o'er-run the stew; laws for all faults, But faults so countenanced, that the strong statutes Stand like the forfeits in a barber's shop, As much in mock as mark.

lines.speaker: escalus
lines.text: Slander to the state! Away with him to prison!

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: What can you vouch against him, Signior Lucio? Is this the man that you did tell us of?

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: 'Tis he, my lord. Come hither, goodman baldpate: do you know me?

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: I remember you, sir, by the sound of your voice: I met you at the prison, in the absence of the duke.

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: O, did you so? And do you remember what you said of the duke?

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: Most notedly, sir.

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: Do you so, sir? And was the duke a fleshmonger, a fool, and a coward, as you then reported him to be?

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: You must, sir, change persons with me, ere you make that my report: you, indeed, spoke so of him; and much more, much worse.

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: O thou damnable fellow! Did not I pluck thee by the nose for thy speeches?

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: I protest I love the duke as I love myself.

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: Hark, how the villain would close now, after his treasonable abuses!

lines.speaker: escalus
lines.text: Such a fellow is not to be talked withal. Away with him to prison! Where is the provost? Away with him to prison! lay bolts enough upon him: let him speak no more. Away with those giglots too, and with the other confederate companion!

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: [To Provost]  Stay, sir; stay awhile.

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: What, resists he? Help him, Lucio.

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: Come, sir; come, sir; come, sir; foh, sir! Why, you bald-pated, lying rascal, you must be hooded, must you? Show your knave's visage, with a pox to you! show your sheep-biting face, and be hanged an hour! Will't not off?
Pulls off the friar's hood, and discovers DUKE VINCENTIO

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: Thou art the first knave that e'er madest a duke. First, provost, let me bail these gentle three. Sneak not away, sir; for the friar and you Must have a word anon. Lay hold on him.
To LUCIO

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: This may prove worse than hanging.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: [To ESCALUS]  What you have spoke I pardon: sit you down: We'll borrow place of him. Sir, by your leave. Hast thou or word, or wit, or impudence, That yet can do thee office? If thou hast, Rely upon it till my tale be heard, And hold no longer out.
To ANGELO

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: O my dread lord, I should be guiltier than my guiltiness, To think I can be undiscernible, When I perceive your grace, like power divine, Hath look'd upon my passes. Then, good prince, No longer session hold upon my shame, But let my trial be mine own confession: Immediate sentence then and sequent death Is all the grace I beg.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: Come hither, Mariana. Say, wast thou e'er contracted to this woman?

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: I was, my lord.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: Go take her hence, and marry her instantly. Do you the office, friar; which consummate, Return him here again. Go with him, provost.
Exeunt ANGELO, MARIANA, FRIAR PETER and Provost

lines.speaker: escalus
lines.text: My lord, I am more amazed at his dishonour Than at the strangeness of it.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: Come hither, Isabel. Your friar is now your prince: as I was then Advertising and holy to your business, Not changing heart with habit, I am still Attorney'd at your service.

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: O, give me pardon, That I, your vassal, have employ'd and pain'd Your unknown sovereignty!

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: You are pardon'd, Isabel: And now, dear maid, be you as free to us. Your brother's death, I know, sits at your heart; And you may marvel why I obscured myself, Labouring to save his life, and would not rather Make rash remonstrance of my hidden power Than let him so be lost. O most kind maid, It was the swift celerity of his death, Which I did think with slower foot came on, That brain'd my purpose. But, peace be with him! That life is better life, past fearing death, Than that which lives to fear: make it your comfort, So happy is your brother.

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: I do, my lord.
Re-enter ANGELO, MARIANA, FRIAR PETER, and Provost

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: For this new-married man approaching here, Whose salt imagination yet hath wrong'd Your well defended honour, you must pardon For Mariana's sake: but as he adjudged your brother,-- Being criminal, in double violation Of sacred chastity and of promise-breach Thereon dependent, for your brother's life,-- The very mercy of the law cries out Most audible, even from his proper tongue, 'An Angelo for Claudio, death for death!' Haste still pays haste, and leisure answers leisure; Like doth quit like, and MEASURE still FOR MEASURE. Then, Angelo, thy fault's thus manifested; Which, though thou wouldst deny, denies thee vantage. We do condemn thee to the very block Where Claudio stoop'd to death, and with like haste. Away with him!

lines.speaker: mariana
lines.text: O my most gracious lord, I hope you will not mock me with a husband.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: It is your husband mock'd you with a husband. Consenting to the safeguard of your honour, I thought your marriage fit; else imputation, For that he knew you, might reproach your life And choke your good to come; for his possessions, Although by confiscation they are ours, We do instate and widow you withal, To buy you a better husband.

lines.speaker: mariana
lines.text: O my dear lord, I crave no other, nor no better man.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: Never crave him; we are definitive.

lines.speaker: mariana
lines.text: Gentle my liege,--
Kneeling

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: You do but lose your labour. Away with him to death! Now, sir, to you.
To LUCIO

lines.speaker: mariana
lines.text: O my good lord! Sweet Isabel, take my part; Lend me your knees, and all my life to come I'll lend you all my life to do you service.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: Against all sense you do importune her: Should she kneel down in mercy of this fact, Her brother's ghost his paved bed would break, And take her hence in horror.

lines.speaker: mariana
lines.text: Isabel, Sweet Isabel, do yet but kneel by me; Hold up your hands, say nothing; I'll speak all. They say, best men are moulded out of faults; And, for the most, become much more the better For being a little bad: so may my husband. O Isabel, will you not lend a knee?

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: He dies for Claudio's death.

lines.speaker: isabella
lines.text: Most bounteous sir, Look, if it please you, on this man condemn'd, As if my brother lived: I partly think A due sincerity govern'd his deeds, Till he did look on me: since it is so, Let him not die. My brother had but justice, In that he did the thing for which he died: For Angelo, His act did not o'ertake his bad intent, And must be buried but as an intent That perish'd by the way: thoughts are no subjects; Intents but merely thoughts.
Kneeling

lines.speaker: mariana
lines.text: Merely, my lord.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: Your suit's unprofitable; stand up, I say. I have bethought me of another fault. Provost, how came it Claudio was beheaded At an unusual hour?

lines.speaker: provost
lines.text: It was commanded so.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: Had you a special warrant for the deed?

lines.speaker: provost
lines.text: No, my good lord; it was by private message.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: For which I do discharge you of your office: Give up your keys.

lines.speaker: provost
lines.text: Pardon me, noble lord: I thought it was a fault, but knew it not; Yet did repent me, after more advice; For testimony whereof, one in the prison, That should by private order else have died, I have reserved alive.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: What's he?

lines.speaker: provost
lines.text: His name is Barnardine.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: I would thou hadst done so by Claudio. Go fetch him hither; let me look upon him.
Exit Provost

lines.speaker: escalus
lines.text: I am sorry, one so learned and so wise As you, Lord Angelo, have still appear'd, Should slip so grossly, both in the heat of blood. And lack of temper'd judgment afterward.

lines.speaker: angelo
lines.text: I am sorry that such sorrow I procure: And so deep sticks it in my penitent heart That I crave death more willingly than mercy; 'Tis my deserving, and I do entreat it.
Re-enter Provost, with BARNARDINE, CLAUDIO muffled, and JULIET

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: Which is that Barnardine?

lines.speaker: provost
lines.text: This, my lord.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: There was a friar told me of this man. Sirrah, thou art said to have a stubborn soul. That apprehends no further than this world, And squarest thy life according. Thou'rt condemn'd: But, for those earthly faults, I quit them all; And pray thee take this mercy to provide For better times to come. Friar, advise him; I leave him to your hand. What muffled fellow's that?

lines.speaker: provost
lines.text: This is another prisoner that I saved. Who should have died when Claudio lost his head; As like almost to Claudio as himself.
Unmuffles CLAUDIO

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: [To ISABELLA]  If he be like your brother, for his sake Is he pardon'd; and, for your lovely sake, Give me your hand and say you will be mine. He is my brother too: but fitter time for that. By this Lord Angelo perceives he's safe; Methinks I see a quickening in his eye. Well, Angelo, your evil quits you well: Look that you love your wife; her worth worth yours. I find an apt remission in myself; And yet here's one in place I cannot pardon. You, sirrah, that knew me for a fool, a coward, One all of luxury, an ass, a madman; Wherein have I so deserved of you, That you extol me thus?
To LUCIO

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: 'Faith, my lord. I spoke it but according to the trick. If you will hang me for it, you may; but I had rather it would please you I might be whipt.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: Whipt first, sir, and hanged after. Proclaim it, provost, round about the city. Is any woman wrong'd by this lewd fellow, As I have heard him swear himself there's one Whom he begot with child, let her appear, And he shall marry her: the nuptial finish'd, Let him be whipt and hang'd.

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: I beseech your highness, do not marry me to a whore. Your highness said even now, I made you a duke: good my lord, do not recompense me in making me a cuckold.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: Upon mine honour, thou shalt marry her. Thy slanders I forgive; and therewithal Remit thy other forfeits. Take him to prison; And see our pleasure herein executed.

lines.speaker: lucio
lines.text: Marrying a punk, my lord, is pressing to death, whipping, and hanging.

lines.speaker: duke vincentio
lines.text: Slandering a prince deserves it. She, Claudio, that you wrong'd, look you restore. Joy to you, Mariana! Love her, Angelo: I have confess'd her and I know her virtue. Thanks, good friend Escalus, for thy much goodness: There's more behind that is more gratulate. Thanks, provost, for thy care and secrecy: We shill employ thee in a worthier place. Forgive him, Angelo, that brought you home The head of Ragozine for Claudio's: The offence pardons itself. Dear Isabel, I have a motion much imports your good; Whereto if you'll a willing ear incline, What's mine is yours and what is yours is mine. So, bring us to our palace; where we'll show What's yet behind, that's meet you all should know.
Exit Officers with LUCIO
Exeunt
